content: The "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" establishes a program to provide grants for projects addressing railroad infrastructure deficiencies to benefit public transportation and reduce energy consumption. Eligible projects aim to mitigate highway traffic congestion, reduce transportation emissions, and improve railroad operations efficiency. Projects eligible for funding under the "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" include increasing track and intermodal yard capacity, acquiring rights-of-way, improving railroad and road crossings, integrating railroad systems, and constructing, repairing, and rehabilitating track structures. Funding cannot be used for operating expenses, rolling stock acquisition, debt payment, or construction of maintenance or passenger facilities. SEC. 103. INCLUSION IN STATE PLANS. Projects must be included in a long-range transportation plan, a State plan, or a transportation improvement program to be funded under this title. SEC. 104. COST SHARING. States must provide at least 20 percent of project costs funded under this title. SEC. 105. ALLOCATION OF FUNDS. The Secretary of Transportation allocates 80% of grant funds to States based on a formula considering rail miles and loaded rail cars. The Secretary of Transportation allocates 80% of grant funds to States based on a formula considering rail miles and loaded rail cars. Additionally, 20% of the grant amount is used for grants for eligible projects of national significance, prioritizing those with the greatest public benefit. The State must report the number of rail miles, loaded and unloaded rail cars, and railroad and public road grade crossings. SEC. 106. LABOR STANDARDS. The Secretary of Transportation must ensure that workers on projects funded under this title are paid prevailing wages. SEC. 107. DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISES. SEC. 107 of the Act mandates that at least 10 percent of the funds be allocated to small businesses owned by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals. Definitions for this section are based on the Transportation Equity Act. SEC. 108 provides additional definitions. SEC. 108 provides definitions for terms used in the Act, including "rail miles" and "railroad." SEC. 201 introduces an excise tax on certain train equipment under a new subchapter on Railroad Locomotives and Rolling Stock in the Internal Revenue Code. "Subchapter E--Railroad Locomotives and Rolling Stock imposes a tax under SEC. 4191." The tax imposed on the sale of specified railroad equipment is 5 percent of the selling price. Specified railroad equipment includes locomotives and other rolling stock. The owner, lessee, or operator installing parts and accessories is subject to regulations set by the Secretary. If specified railroad equipment owners install parts or accessories within 6 months of placing the equipment in service, a 5% tax is imposed on the installation cost. This tax does not apply to replacement parts or accessories. The 5% tax on installation cost applies to specified railroad equipment owners within 6 months of placing the equipment in service. Replacement parts or accessories are exempt from this tax. Installers are secondarily liable for the tax imposed. The amendments for railroad locomotives and rolling stock will be effective on October 1, 2003. A new subchapter on transportation by rail is added to the Internal Revenue Code, including a tax on rail transportation of persons or property. A new subchapter on transportation by rail is added to the Internal Revenue Code, including a tax on rail transportation of persons or property. This subchapter includes sections on transportation of persons, transportation of property, and definitions and special rules. The Internal Revenue Code includes a tax on rail transportation of persons, with a 5% tax for commuter rail and a 10% tax for other cases. The tax is paid by the person making the payment. A 1% tax is imposed on the amount paid for taxable rail transportation of property within or outside the United States. The tax applies to payments made to a person engaged in the business of transporting property by rail for hire. The person making the payment is responsible for paying the tax, except for payments made outside the United States. Payments subject to tax under subsection (a) made outside the United States require the person receiving the property in the US to pay the tax if the person making the payment does not. The tax will be collected by the entity providing the last segment of the taxable transportation. SEC. 4243 defines terms and special rules related to tax payments for property received in the US from payments made outside the country. For tax purposes, "taxable rail transportation" refers to rail travel within the US, excluding mass transit. The term "transportation" includes layover time and deadhead service movement. Special rules apply to payments made outside the US for prepaid orders. When refunding a ticket purchased without tax, the person must deduct any tax due under section 4241 from the refund amount. The remaining uncollected tax must be reported to the Secretary. The carrier must pay any tax remaining uncollected from the transportation purchased with a ticket, as required by section 4241. If the tax is not paid at the time of transportation payment, the carrier providing the initial segment in the US is responsible for paying the tax. The carrier responsible for paying any remaining uncollected tax on transportation purchased with a ticket in the US. A clerical amendment is made to the table of subchapters for chapter 33 of the Code. SEC. 203. NATIONAL RAIL INFRASTRUCTURE PROGRAM TRUST FUND. The amendments made by this section will be effective on October 1, 2003. Subchapter A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section establishing the National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund is created in the Treasury of the United States, funded by taxes on railroad locomotives, rolling stock, and a portion of customs duties. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund is funded by taxes on railroad locomotives, rolling stock, customs duties, fuel taxes, and royalties from oil or gas extraction on Federal lands. Amounts in the fund can only be used for expenditures related to the National Rail Infrastructure Program Act. The Program Trust Fund is available for expenditures under the National Rail Infrastructure Program Act. Sec. 9511. National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund is available for expenditures under the National Rail Infrastructure Program Act.
